text: you know I've had the interesting uh the
interesting career of uh training for
many things uh and then having a career
mostly in things I never trained
for after graduate school I became a um
postto with Steven Hawking uh where we
were working on quantum theories of
gravity basically they were trying to
understand the fundamental structure of
space and time and where the universe
came from uh I took a leave of absence
from that to work on a software project
was supposed to be for 3 month months
and it turned out to be for the rest of
my life after a couple months working on
this software project we decided to
start a company uh I became the CEO of
that company uh we ran the company for
two years uh then Microsoft bought us
and I became the first Chief technology
officer at Microsoft uh where I was for
14 years uh worked directly for Bill
Gates and uh was able to participate in
the PC Revolution it's a magic time
because software uh through personal
computing empowered literally billions
of people to take charge of the
information in their lives to be
creative whether it was with a word
processor or a spread sheet or an art
package uh uh leading up ultimately to
the internet which is the ultimate
information distribution system for the
planet now along the way I've been
interested in a dozen other things uh
I've always been interested in science
uh after training in many fields of
science uh I didn't actually profess
professionally pursue them but I have
been interested in dinosaurs for example
for the last 15 years I've done a lot of
dinosaur research um published a number
of papers on dinosaurs a and uh have
been the main sponsor and co-led an
expedition with Jack Herer uh where we
found uh more T-Rexes than anyone else
in the world's ever found T-Rexes and
lots of other dinosaurs besides that
when I retired from Microsoft uh that
was a difficult thing to do because I
was very successful at Microsoft I was
Chief technology officer uh of the
company uh it was still an amazing time
for the company and for technology now
of course once I'd been at Microsoft for
a while I had the the resources where I
could start over and it wasn't like I
was afraid of starving um but it it is
always an issue when you're good at
something to say do I keep getting
better at that thing or do I switch to
something else for me it's been pretty
easy to switch to other things because I
get interested in them and once I get
interested in them uh there's no turning
back so
it's always difficult to leave something
you know for something you don't
particularly if you're good at it um if
you're not good at it and you get fired
or you screw up it's easy to leave the
world forces that on you but if it's
your decision it's tough but it's also
your life and if you don't take charge
of it no one will take charge of it for
you uh the only institution in life
where you get time off for good behavior
is prison um you know in most jobs or
most careers the better you are at it
the more you're sucked into it you get
the big promotion you get more
responsibility you get more success and
that tends to narrow your options not
increase them but what's the point of
success if you don't have your own
options and you don't make your own
decision um so for that reason I decided
I had to really make a decision and
ultimately I decided I would leave
Microsoft uh and as great as that
experience was for me at Microsoft I'm
thrilled that I left and I've uh made
something of a life for myself since
then
